[[File:United States Army Medical Department Museum.jpg|thumb|right|Entrance]] The '''U.S. Army Medical Department Museum''' — or '''AMEDD Museum''' — at [[Fort Sam Houston]], [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], originated as part of the Army's [[Field Service School]] at [[Carlisle Barracks]], Pennsylvania. It moved to Fort Sam Houston in 1946. It is currently a component of the [[U.S. Army Medical Department Center and School]].
The [[museum]] features the history of the [[Army Medical Department (United States)|Army Medical Department]] from 1775 to the present, as well as medical contributions of the Army during times of [[peace]] and [[war]]. General areas covered are significant historical events, scientific and technological advances, development of the medical field service and contributions of key officers and enlisted personnel. Audio-visual presentations introduce the history of the Department. Two large galleries house the medical equipment, [[military uniform|uniforms]], [[medal]]s, [[Army Medical Department (United States)#Badges|insignia]] and artwork that make up the museum's exhibits. Museum holdings include material on medical personnel, [[prisoner of war|POWs]] in [[World War II]]'s [[Pacific War|Pacific Theater]], unit insignia and archival documents and photographs.
The museum has been chosen to preserve historic artifacts from [http://www.med.navy.mil/sites/navmedmpte/nhcs-gl/Pages/default.asp Navy Hospital Corps School Great Lakes]. BRAC 2005 resulted in transferred of Corps School from Chicago to the [[Medical Education and Training Campus]] (METC), also located on Fort Sam Houston. [http://www.defense.gov/brac/]
==Exhibits== Specific displays of interest include: *Dr. [[William Beaumont]], the Army surgeon known as the "Father of Gastric Physiology" * Brigadier General [[George Miller Sternberg|George Sternberg]], MD, the Surgeon General known as the "Father of American Bacteriology" * MASH ([[Mobile Army Surgical Hospital]]) units in [[Korean War|Korea]] * [[Medical evacuation|Medical air evac]] in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] * [[Combat Medic]] [[Medal of Honor]] recipients (43 from 1861 to 1970) * Images of all (but one) of the [[Surgeons General of the United States Army|Army Surgeons General]] * Aftermath of the 1876 [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]] in Montana
[[File:United States Army Medical Rail Car.jpg|thumb|Hospital train ambulance car]] Outside the museum are examples of medical vehicles including [[Ambulance#Military use|ambulances]] and a fully equipped hospital train ambulance car. A Medical Combat Memorial honors the Army's combat medics.
